Award.AwardTitle: CIF: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2019 IEEE Workshop on Signal Processing Advances in Wireless Communications (SPAWC 2019)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides travel support for up to ten students from US institutions to participate in 2019 IEEE International Workshop on Signal Processing Advances for Wireless Communications (SPAWC), which will take place in Cannes, France, July 2-5, 2019. SPAWC is one of the flagship annual conferences of the IEEE Signal Processing Society and will be celebrating its 20th anniversary in 2019. SPAWC is devoted to dissemination of advances in signal processing for wireless communications, networking, and information theory. The workshop's Organizing Committee and Technical Program Committee, which change from year to year, comprise eminent scientists from around the world working at the intersection of communications, signal processing and information theory. SPAWC offers a unique format for dissemination of ideas by mixing keynotes with poster presentations, making participation more interactive than many other conferences. It is a small (usually 150-250 participants every year) but very focused conference, which affords deeper interactions among the participants. Papers submitted to SPAWC are peer-reviewed and accepted papers are published as a proceedings volume and digitally archived on IEEE Xplore.

Student activities include a best student paper contest, luncheons with keynote speakers, and mentoring opportunities for underrepresented groups. The students supported on this travel award will have ample opportunities to network with their peers, mentors, and eminent researchers in this field, and will provide testimonials on the outcomes of this activity at the end of the workshop.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The IEEE International Workshop on Signal Processing Advances for Wireless Communications (SPAWC), which celebrated its 20th anniversary in 2019, is one of the flagship annual conferences of the IEEE Signal Processing Society that is devoted to dissemination of advances in signal processing for wireless communications, networking, and information theory. This project provided travel support to students from US institutions so that they could participate in 2019 edition of the SPAWC workshop, which took place in Cannes, France from July 2 to July 5, 2019. The technical program of SPAWC 2019 revolved around the emerging themes of:

  • Machine learning for communications
  • Network control, distributed robotics, and drones
  • Sparsity and compressed sensing in communications
  • 5G communications and beyond

The award selection committee originally selected 10 students for awarding of the travel grants, with 1 being an undergraduate student and 9 being graduate students. Within this cohort of selected students, 50% belonged to underrepresented minority (URM) groups in engineering and 20% belonged to the category of beginning researchers and did not have a paper in the workshop. Because of various logistical challenges, 3 of the students could not make it to the workshop, resulting in the project funds being disbursed to the remaining 7 students. Within this cohort of awardees, 57% belonged to URM groups and 14% belonged to the category of beginning researchers.

The travel grants awarded as part of this project enabled the 7 student awardees to learn about emerging research areas at the intersection of signal processing, communications, and information theory and to network with other researchers and leading academic and industrial experts in their research areas of interest. The workshop also provided plenty of opportunities for the student awardees to network with their peers and senior researchers in semi-formal settings. Student participants presenting their research papers at SPAWC 2019 also benefitted greatly from immediate feedback on their research from more accomplished researchers. All this is expected to have a tremendous positive impact on the future research careers of the awardees, which will include finalizing the topics for their research theses, learning about the questions that they need to ask in their respective fields of research, and finding research mentors and/or role models for their research careers.
